title: Male Figure (Nkisi Nkondi) (Power, Movement, Spirit)
transcript:
Cecile Fromont: What we are looking at is a figure that is part of a category of objects from central Africa that are known as nkisi.

<music>

Cecile Fromont: My name is Cecile Fromont and I am a associate professor of art history at Yale University. Nkisi are basically a set of invisible forces that can be manipulated if they are ensnared or seduced into particular containers by ritual practitioners.

<music>

Cecile Fromont: So basically, the object is made of two cards [ph?], two categories of material. There is the sculpture itself, the wood that has been shaped into the figure of a person. Then, the other side are the nails and pieces that are added later on, and, in particular, to parts which are the box on his stomach, which is containing a set of ingredients that the ritual practitioner has used to seduce that particular nkisi invisible force into that particular container.

<music>

Cecile Fromont: So the larger and public nkisis, such as this one, are really a type of objects that belong to a community. And the community would have recourse to that object, to some extent as a witness of agreements that are being made between different members of the community or between two different communities. It's, in a way, something that is similar as signing a document. So it could be one of those nails that are such prominent features of the object that are each probably linked to a particular activation, to a particular contract, to a particular agreement that would have been made through this figure.

<music>
